# Project Description

This project examines the alignment between skills required in AI job adverts and those taught in UK AI degree programs. It analyzes two datasets:


1. <a href="extras/jobDataset.zip" target="_blank" style="color:#0077B5; text-decoration:none;" 
   onmouseover="this.style.color='darkblue'" 
   onmouseout="this.style.color='#0077B5';">
   **Job Advertisements Dataset**
</a> : Skills extracted from AI-related job adverts on LinkedIn.

2. <a href="extras/uniDataset.zip" target="_blank" style="color:#0077B5; text-decoration:none;" 
   onmouseover="this.style.color='darkblue'" 
   onmouseout="this.style.color='#0077B5';">
   **University Courses Dataset**
</a> : Skills extracted from official UK university course pages.


The goal is to identify skill gaps and trends to inform curriculum development for better alignment with industry needs.

# Technologies Used
- <span style="font-weight: bold;">`Python`</span>: For data preprocessing, web scraping, and NLP pipelines.
- <span style="font-weight: bold;">`pandas`</span> and <span style="font-weight: bold;">`NumPy`</span>: For data cleaning and transformation.
- <span style="font-weight: bold;">`Scikit-learn`</span>: For training and evaluation (87% precision) of the <span style="font-weight: bold;">`Naïve Bayes`</span> predictive modeling.
- <span style="font-weight: bold;">`Matplotlib`</span>: To create insightful data visualizations.
- <span style="font-weight: bold;">`Clay`</span>: Third-party scraper for LinkedIn job advertisements (adheres to scraping limits).
- <span style="font-weight: bold;">`n-grams`</span> and <span style="font-weight: bold;">`Regex`</span>: For extracting and cleaning multi-word skill phrases from datasets.
- <span style="font-weight: bold;">`Naïve Bayes`</span>: Machine learning model for categorizing skills into 12 predefined categories.
- <span style="font-weight: bold;">`VSCode`</span>: Integrated development environment (IDE) for writing, debugging, and managing code.

# Report Summary

## Data Collection
- **Jobs**: Scraped 158 LinkedIn ads using Clay, adhering to legal limits.  
- **Universities**: Manually collected AI course data from the top 30 UK universities.  

## Processing & Analysis
- Extracted skill phrases using n-grams and categorized them with a Naïve Bayes model into 12 skill areas.  
- Compared skills across datasets to identify gaps, overlaps, and trends.

## Key Findings
- Both focus on **Programming**, **Software Development**, and **Machine Learning**.  
- Job ads prioritize **Data Science**, **Business**, and **Soft Skills** like communication and analytical thinking.  
- Universities emphasize technical expertise, with minor gaps in **general knowledge** and **analytical thinking**.  
- Growing importance of **Ethics** recognized by both.

## Conclusion
Employers seek well-rounded candidates, blending technical and non-technical skills, emphasizing the need for academic curricula to adapt.  

## Future Work
- Expanding datasets, exploring alternative classifiers, and conducting qualitative research can enhance findings.
